question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answers and \textbf{show
all your work.} Simplification of answers is not required.

Evaluate the following integral.

\[\int_1^2 \frac{e^{1/x}}{x^2}\,dx.\]
sols:
We follow the hints and first rewrite the integral.

\[\int_1^2 \frac{e^{1/x}}{x^2}\,dx = \int_1^2 x^{-2}e^{x^{-1}}\,dx.\]
Now we substitute

\[u = x^{-1}, \quad \frac{du}{dx} = -x^{-2}, \quad dx = -x^2\,du.\]
Further, for $x=1$ we have $u=1$, and for $x=2$ we have $u=1/2$.
Therefore,

\begin{align*}
\int_1^2 x^{-2}e^{x^{-1}}\,dx &= \int_1^{1/2} x^{-2}e^u(-x^2\,du) \\
&= -\int_1^{1/2} e^u\,du \\
&= \int_{1/2}^1 e^u\,du \\
&= \left.e^{u}\right|_{1/2}^1 \\
&= e-e^{1/2}.
\end{align*}
hints:
Maybe it helps to rewrite the integrand as

\[\frac{e^{1/x}}{x^2} = x^{-2} e^{x^{-1}}.\]
